title: Weather unlikely to disrupt April elections, says Election Commission
content: The Election Commission has stated that weather conditions are expected to have little impact on the provincial and local elections scheduled for April. Spokesperson Sushil Acharya said that the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology forecasts clear skies across hilly and Terai regions during the election period, with minimal chance of rainfall. The assessment is based on weather data trends collected over the past 30 years, the department informed the commission on Tuesday.

title: Human-elephant conflict remains a hot election topic in Chitwan
content: Farmers in Chitwan district report that expanding forest reserves and increasing elephant habitats have intensified human-elephant conflicts. Crop damage and property loss have risen, forcing some farmers to switch crops or take seasonal jobs outside agriculture. With the elections approaching, local candidates have made elephant management a major campaign issue, promising electric fencing, compensation schemes, and improved wildlife protection policies.

title: Polling stations ready as March elections near
content: The Election Commission has confirmed that polling stations across Nepal are fully prepared for the upcoming House of Representatives elections on March 5. Officials say security personnel and election materials have been deployed nationwide, and training for staff has been completed. Commission spokesperson Narayan Prasad Bhattarai emphasized that logistical arrangements are in place even in remote hilly and mountainous regions.

title: Flood-prone areas see safety measures ahead of polls
content: Authorities in Terai districts have installed temporary flood barriers and evacuation plans in low-lying areas ahead of the March elections. Local officials noted that river levels have remained stable, but contingency measures are being maintained as a precaution. Election candidates have also engaged with communities to ensure voters in vulnerable areas can safely participate.

title: Wild boar damage sparks campaign promises in Kavre
content: Farmers in Kavre district report increasing crop damage from wild boars, particularly in areas bordering forests. As elections approach, candidates have highlighted the issue, promising better fencing, compensation for losses, and coordination with wildlife authorities. Local agricultural offices say awareness campaigns are ongoing to mitigate conflict between wildlife and farming communities.

title: Mountain roads cleared to ensure voter access
content: The Department of Roads has prioritized clearing and maintaining mountain roads leading to polling stations ahead of the March 5 elections. Spokesperson Sushil Acharya stated that heavy machinery and local contractors are on standby to prevent disruptions caused by landslides or snow. The Election Commission confirmed that all remote voters will have access to polling stations.

title: Bird nuisance debated in Lalitpur ahead of elections
content: Residents in Lalitpur district have raised concerns over increasing bird populations damaging crops and property. As election campaigns intensify, local candidates have promised measures such as bird deterrents, monitoring programs, and public awareness initiatives. Experts note that while conservation is important, mitigation strategies are needed to protect farmers' livelihoods.

title: Election Commission assures safe voting in hilly districts
content: The Election Commission has assured voters that all safety measures are in place for polling in Nepal's hilly districts. Spokesperson Narayan Prasad Bhattarai said polling staff have been trained in emergency response and medical support is available at remote stations. The commission emphasized that no major disruptions are expected during the elections.

title: Landslide-prone areas monitored for smooth polling
content: Authorities in Sindhupalchok and Ramechhap districts are closely monitoring landslide-prone areas as March elections approach. Early warning systems and local volunteers have been mobilized to ensure voters can reach polling stations safely. Candidates have also engaged with communities to assist those living in vulnerable locations.

title: Monsoon-like showers unlikely to affect Terai voters
content: Meteorologists predict dry conditions in Terai districts during the upcoming provincial elections. The Department of Hydrology and Meteorology informed the Election Commission that rainfall is unlikely during the polling period. Officials say contingency plans are ready but anticipate minimal weather-related disruptions.

title: Human-wildlife conflict rises in Sunsari ahead of polls
content: Residents of Sunsari district report increasing encounters with monkeys and wild boars affecting farmland. As elections near, local politicians have promised solutions including compensation for crop loss, construction of protective barriers, and stronger collaboration with wildlife authorities.

title: Election Commission launches voter awareness drive
content: The Election Commission has initiated a nationwide campaign to inform citizens about polling procedures and voter rights ahead of March 5 elections. The campaign includes radio broadcasts, community workshops, and social media updates to ensure high voter turnout across urban and rural areas.

title: Remote polling stations equipped with solar power
content: In far western districts of Nepal, the Election Commission has installed solar-powered equipment in remote polling stations. Spokesperson Sushil Acharya said this initiative ensures that even areas without reliable electricity can conduct elections smoothly.

title: Community volunteers assist elderly voters
content: Local communities in Dhading and Gorkha districts have mobilized volunteers to help elderly and differently-abled citizens reach polling stations safely. Election officials noted that this initiative is crucial for inclusive voter participation, particularly in hilly regions with difficult terrain.

title: Wildlife corridors considered in election logistics
content: Election planners in Bardiya and Banke districts are taking wildlife corridors into account to minimize human-animal conflicts during the polls. Officials have coordinated with conservation authorities to ensure both voter safety and protection of endangered species.

title: Transportation services ramped up for rural voters
content: Local authorities in Kailali and Kanchanpur districts have increased bus and jeep services to transport rural voters to polling stations. Candidates have praised the initiative, emphasizing the importance of inclusive access to voting in remote communities.

title: Crop-raiding elephants spark pre-election debate
content: In Jhapa and Morang districts, elephants entering farmland have caused significant damage to crops. Election candidates have raised the issue, promising mitigation measures such as community fencing, early warning systems, and wildlife compensation programs to protect farmersâ€™ livelihoods.

title: Election safety drills conducted across mountainous regions
content: The Election Commission has conducted safety drills in mountainous districts to prepare polling staff for emergencies such as landslides, heavy snowfall, or medical incidents. Officials say these drills are part of a larger effort to ensure smooth elections across all terrains.

title: Voter turnout expected to be high despite remote terrain
content: Officials in Solukhumbu and Dolakha districts predict strong voter turnout despite challenging terrain. Election Commission spokesperson Narayan Prasad Bhattarai said logistics have been coordinated with local authorities, and community volunteers will assist residents in reaching polling stations.

title: Farmers' concerns about monkeys remain key election issue
content: In Dhankuta and Okhaldhunga districts, farmers report growing crop damage due to monkey populations. Political candidates have made monkey management a major campaign promise, offering fencing solutions, compensation schemes, and community awareness programs to address the issue.
